newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan's Aqaba discharges 51,058 T sugar for Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Jordan's Aqaba discharges 51,058 T sugar for Iraq.

text.p: Four vessels with 51,058 tonnes of Brazilian sugar for both the Iraqi government and re-sale to private Iraqi traders, were unloading at Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba, shippers said on Thursday.
Two sugar cargoes are direct state purchases, the St. Vincent-flag Dalia with 9,000 tonnes and the Ukraine-flag Kapitan Kaminskiy with a consignment of 14,058 tonnes.
Traders say the 14,058 tonnes consignment was arranged on deferred payment terms for Iraq by a London-based trader.
The other two consignments, 14,000 tonnes each, are for re-export in small lots via free zones to private Iraqi traders, shippers said.
The first is on the Cypriot-flagged Panadros which arrived on Wednesday and the second on the Cypriot-flagged Nearchos arrived on Tuesday.
Traders say the prices of Brazilian sugar purchased averaged $410 per tonne, c and f.
Grain traders say another two vessels with 28,000 tonnes of Brazilian sugar imported by Jordanian traders are expected to unload at the free zone in September.
Traders say the shipments are the first sugar cargoes bought by both Iraq and Jordanian traders for re-export to Iraqi private traders in recent months.
They say loading problems in Brazil have delayed most of the cargoes, which should have arrived at least a month ago.
Aqaba's free zone sugar stockile was virtually empty, although it can hold at least 30,000 tonnes. Jordanian traders stockpile sugar that Iraqi traders buy in small to medium-sized lots for cash.
Jordanian traders said Iraq has bought small shipments of Dubai sugar re-exports because of the shortage in the Aqaba free zone.

Jordanian agents for international sugar suppliers have sounded out Iraqi state buyers but few deals have been clinched since Baghdad signed a deal last May that allows Iraqi oil exports worth $2 billion over six months.
Traders say Iraq was ready to start ordering food but was delayed because the U.N. accord's implementation mechanism was not complete.

Jordanian traders said Iraq's oil-for-food pact will change the suppy pattern, which depended mainly on private Iraqi purchases. The pact lets the Baghdad government purchase from suppliers the bulk of its food needs.
